awd_titl_txt: Photochemistry on Atmospheric Aerosols; Fundamental Reaction Dynamics of Sunlight Initiated Processing of Organic Molecules in Aqueous Environments
awd_abstract_narration: The Environmental Chemical Science (ECS) program will support the collaborative research project of Profs. Veronica Vaida and Rex Skodje of the University of Colorado at Boulder. The collaborating investigators and their students will employ a combination of theoretical modeling and advanced laser-based spectroscopic methods including cavity ringdown and cavity enhanced spectroscopy to study the effect of water on the formation and chemical reactivity of secondary organic aerosols. The project will increase our molecular level understanding of secondary organic aerosols and contribute to increasing the accuracy of prediction of climate models. The project will provide excellent training opportunities to undergraduate and graduate students in a cutting edge research area of great societal importance.

por.por_cntn:
The ability to calculate the chemical composition, radiative transfer and fluid flow of the earth’s atmosphere as it evolves in space and time has become of paramount importance in ensuring the habitability of the planet. Such calculations are only possible if the processes that determine the chemical composition of the air are understood and quantitatively formulated. The role of organic species has become increasingly important, particularly in modeling the role of aerosols and clouds. The study performed with NSF support addressed fundamental issues of light initiated organic atmospheric chemistry mediated by water. The intellectual merit in this investigation stems from addressing fundamental aspects of sunlight-initiated chemistry of organic molecules, mediated or catalyzed by water. The temperature, climate, and chemistry of the planet are fuelled by sunlight. Over the temperature and pressure range in the Earth’s atmosphere, water in all phases plays an important role in mediating atmospheric chemistry and climate. In an interdisciplinary effort involving theory and experiment specific issues were addressed.

(1) The study extended the understanding of atmospheric photochemistry to the study of vibrationally excited processes driven by red light.

(2) The water mediated hydration of the carbonyl group changes the electronic states of the molecule. UV photochemistry of gas phase aldehydes and ketones has been investigated in the literature but the photochemistry of the their hydrates (polyalcohols) is as yet unknown. New theoretical and experimental approaches to simulate the photoreactivity of organic species in the aerosol environment been developed and have shown that water may catalyze mediate or suppress organic chemical reactions. The water effect on organic chemical reactions is dynamically controlled.

(3) In aqueous environments, chemistry is altered from the gas phase. Photochemical reaction mechanisms are phase and environment dependent. Fundamental chemical processes in aqueous environments, at the water-air interface and in/on aqueous aerosols have been investigated. Using the example of pyruvic acid, theory worked with laboratory experiments and environmental simulation chamber studies to obtain results relevant to formation of secondary organic aerosols, results included in atmospheric models.

This interdisciplinary study derives broader impact from the widely acknowledged importance of organic species, water and aerosols for climate and global change. The work performed involved interdisciplinary collaboration between theory and experiment and through an international collaboration employed an environmental chamber to connect fundamental laboratory results with processing in the atmosphere consequently providing ideal and far-reaching opportunities for education. Teaching of chemistry through environmental problems has been pursued in classroom and outreach settings. In undergraduate and graduate courses examples from environmental chemistry have been incorporated. An interesting aspect of the work performed involved collaboration and student exchanges with groups in France and Denmark and informing and preparing our students for a global scientific environment. This project targeted students from diverse backgrounds who have been offered mentoring in professional development, through participation in this project.
